In recent years, publications on how to improve hydrodesulfurization catalysts have decreased considerably. However, the presence of sulfur compounds in oil cuts continues to increase and still represents a challenge to comply with environmental regulations. In this direction, improving hydrodesulfurization catalysts is of paramount importance. The present study focuses on combining two approaches to modify the alumina surface and bulk properties, namely, using an ordered porous structure and doping it with yttrium. We synthesized AlY-x (x as 0, 0.5, 1.0, and 1.5 yttrium substitutions in a alumina unit cell) materials via a one-pot solgel route assisted by citric acid and P-123. The samples were calcined at 800 °C and 1000 °C to determine their stability. The support samples were subsequently used to prepare NiW/AlY-x catalysts to be applied in hydrodesulfurization (HDS) reactions via 3-methyl-thiophene (3MT), dibenzothiophene (DBT), as naphtha and diesel sulfur model compounds. The results indicate that yttrium promotes stability, enhances textural properties, increases the CO2 adsorption capacity and changes the acidbase properties of the supports. In the case of the NiW/AlY-x catalyst, the presence of yttrium results in better dispersion, decreasing the WS2 slabs and improving the participation of Ni in the nonstoichiometric NiWS active phase . These improvements led to selectivity resulting almost exclusively from the direct desulfurization route. Among all the catalysts tested, NiW/AlY-1.0 resulted in approximately 4.6 times greater activity than the yttrium-free sample. Graphical Abstract Keywords Hydrodesulfurization Ordered mesoporous alumina XPS NiW Yttrium Metal oxides Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Different strategies and methodologies are used to enhance the properties of several metal oxides. These methods typically involve the preparation of catalysts for a wide variety of applications [1]. For example, in catalysis, studies have focused on improving textural properties, tuning porosity, and hierarchical structure to increase active phase dispersion. This, at the same time, enhances the diffusion of reactants and products [2–4]. These intended textural properties are commonly exhibited by ordered porous materials such as SBA-15 or KIT-16 [5–7]. However, owing to their low metal support interaction, efforts have been made to emulate the chemistry of these molecular sieves to obtain their ordered porosity with other metal oxide systems [8,9]. Various metal oxides beyond common aluminosilicates and silicates, including TiO2, SiO2, WO3, MgO, and obviously alumina, have been explored [10–12]. Alumina remains a highly popular material among catalyst supports because of its excellent mechanical stability and favorable textural properties. Over the years, research has focused on developing alumina with other properties that could enhance its usability and durability, providing it with a mesoporous ordered structure [13]. However, achieving such ordered porosity is often hindered by the difficulty of controlling factors such as aluminum hydrolysis, evolution of the structural phase, and control over the water and moisture contents. For example, Niesz et al. presented an evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) method to produce mesoporous ordered alumina using aluminum isopropoxide [14]. This approach requires strict control over humidity and an inert atmosphere during the solvent evaporation stage. Similarly, Yuan et al. successfully synthesized alumina with a high degree of order and desirable textural and chemical properties, making it suitable for use as a catalyst support [15]. This was accomplished via the use of various aluminum precursors, citric acid, and a triblock copolymer. Despite these promising results, their method has low reproducibility and some inconsistencies, as most subsequent papers have been unable to replicate their published results. Stacy et al. demonstrated the effect of acid concentration on this synthesis; nevertheless, their materials exhibit a pseudo-ordered pore structure [16]. Pan et al. reported synthesis via the same procedure described by Yuan et al., highlighting that solvothermal treatments could enhance the formation of ordered structures [17]. However, as mentioned above, the use of metal oxides as supports is another common strategy to improve the performance of catalytic materials [18–20]. Some typical methods of preparation include incipient wetness impregnation, precipitation, and solgel methods, among others [21]. The role of basic supports such as magnesium oxide or alkali and earth metals, such as Y, La, Sc, and Nd, are widely studied because of their ability to improve the catalytic stability and modulate the acidbase properties of alumina, principally to inhibit olefin hydrogenation [22–27]. Additionally, these metals are of interest in reactions where modifying surface interactions with the active phase is desirable, such as in hydrodesulfurization catalysts [28]. Some studies have investigated alumina doped with rare earth metals for hydrogenation, methane reforming, and hydrodesulfurization [18,29–31]. [30] These studies confirmed that rare earth metals generally improve catalytic performance by increasing thermal stability, modifying surface acidity, and preventing deactivation due to coke formation. Our research group has extensively studied the effects of gallium and yttrium as mixed oxides and dopants [32–36]. Our findings indicated that the presence of yttrium drastically changes the selectivity of the alcohol dehydration reaction and modifies the general morphology of the alumina-yttria mixed oxides with different yttria contents [35,36]. Therefore, in this study, we aimed to combine ordered pore alumina and incorporate different quantities of yttrium as a dopant during synthesis. These support samples were used to prepare NiW hydrodesulfurization (HDS) catalysts for evaluating the removal of sulfur from 3-methylthiophene (3MT) and dibenzothiophene (DBT) model molecules. The prepared support samples and catalysts were extensively characterized in both the oxide and sulfide states. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Support preparation Mesoporous pseudo-ordered alumina doped with yttrium was prepared via a solgel method assisted by citric acid. Four materials were prepared, including dopant-free alumina and three materials with different yttrium contents. This material series was named AlY-x, where x equals 0, 0.5, 1.0, and 1.5, corresponding to the yttrium substitution at a 24-cation sites of a typical spinel unit cell. This substitution led to nominal yttrium/aluminum molar ratios of 0.021, 0.042, and 0.063. The synthesis was adapted from Pan et al. and Yuan et al. [15,17] and uses P-123 as a surfactant and aluminum nitrate nonahydrate and yttrium nitrate hexaydrate as metal precursors. The following molar ratio was used to prepare the materials: Al:P-123:ethanol:HCl:citric acid = 1.0:0.024:33.6:0.029:0.21. Two solutions, A and B, were prepared. Solution A was prepared by dissolving P-123 in ethanol at 40 °C under vigorous stirring. After P-123 was completely dissolved, HCl (0.5 M) was added, and the mixture was stirred for 4 h. Solution B was prepared by dissolving a fixed quantity of citric acid in ethanol for 15 min, followed by the dissolution of aluminum nitrate nonahydrate. This B solution was stirred vigorously for 1 h. Solutions A and B were then combined and stirred at 40 °C for another 24 h. The resulting homogeneous and transparent solution was transferred to a Teflon container for solvothermal treatment at 80 °C for 24 h. After this, a viscous solution was obtained and placed in a crystallizer at 60 °C for 2 days. The white powder samples were calcined at 400 °C via a heating ramp of 1 °C·min−1 and then further calcined at 800 °C for 3 h. 2.2 Catalyst preparation These materials were impregnated via the incipient wetness method via a solution of nickel nitrate and ammonium metatungstate, with water used as the solvent. The volume of the incorporated solution matched the pore volume of each support, controlling the metal loading at 2.8 tungsten atoms per square nanometer, with a Ni/(Ni+W) ratio of 0.31, to fairly compare the samples and avoid misinterpretation due to possible differences in the surface area [37]. After impregnation, the solids were dried at ambient temperature for 24 h, followed by calcination at 450 °C for 2 h. This series of materials was named NiW/AlY-x. 2.3 Materials characterization The textural properties of the materials were determined from the adsorptiondesorption isotherms of nitrogen at −196 °C, which were recorded with a Micromeritics (TriStar II) apparatus. Prior to analysis, approximately 250 mg of each sample was degassed under vacuum at 300 °C for 3 h. A total of 92 data points were collected for adsorption and desorption isotherms over the P/P0 range of 0.002–0.995. The specific surface areas of the samples were calculated via the BrunauerEmmettTeller (BET) method considering 12 points across the P/P0 range of 0.03–0.24, and the BET C constants (CBET) are reported in the supplementary information. The pore size distribution curves were calculated via the BarrettJoynerHalenda (BJH) method applied to the desorption branch, and the total volume of pores was estimated at P/P0 = 0.99. Zeta potential curves were obtained via a Malver Zetasizer Nano equipped with an MPT-2 Autotitrator employing 0.01 M NaCl as the electrolyte. Titrations were made using 0.01 M HCl and NaOH solutions. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of CO2 was performed in a fixed-bed quartz reactor connected to a mass spectrometer (HIDEN HPR20 QMS). Prior to analysis, the sample was treated at 700 °C for 1 h under 5 % O2/He flow (30 cm³·min−1). The reactor was cooled to 50 °C under a constant flow of He, saturated with 50 % CO2/He for 30 min and purged with He for 25 min. TPD was performed by heating at 10 °C·min−1 until 700 °C was reached. The concentrations of Al, Y, W, and Ni were obtained via inductively coupled plasmaoptical emission spectrometry (ICPOES Varian Vista-MPX CCD simultaneously). Prior to analysis, the samples were ground and dried at 120 °C for 2 h. Subsequently, 15 mg of each sample were weighed and digested in 3 mL of a mixed acid mixture of HCl, HNO3, and HF. The mixture was then carefully agitated and maintained for 72 h at room temperature. After this period, the solutions were sonicated for 30 min and diluted to 100 mL with deionized water. For calibration, monoelemental standards (Sigma Aldrich) were used to prepare solutions of 0.2, 5.0, and 30.0 mg·L−1, whereas for Y, 0.2, 5.0, and 15.0 mg·L−1 solutions were used. Measurements were performed in triplicate, and blank analyses were conducted via the same procedure. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were acquired via a JEOL JEM-2010FEG field emission electron microscope. Around 15 micrographs were acquired for each sample for statistical purposes. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted via a TA Instrument Q500 instrument under air flow (60 mL· min−1) with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 up to 800 °C. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were recorded with an Aeris Malvern Panalytical diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 30 mA) at a wavelength of 0.154 nm. The measurement parameters were as follows: 2θ between 20° and 80°, with a size and step time of 0.5° and 0.02 s, respectively. Diffuse reflectance UVvis spectroscopy (UVVis DRS) was carried out with a Cary 5000 UVVis spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed with a SPECS® spectrometer with a PHOIBOS® 150 WAL hemispherical energy analyzer with angular resolution (< 0.5 degrees) equipped with XR 50 X-ray and μ-FOCUS 500 X-ray monochromator (Al excitation line) sources. A flood gun was used to avoid surface charging effects during the XPS analysis with 10 micro amperes of emission current, an energy of 1 eV, and a filament current of 3 amperes. The binding energies (BEs) were referenced to the C 1 s peak (284.8 eV) to compensate for possible charging effects. After activation, the samples were kept under a N2 atmosphere before analysis, as described previously [38]. The sulfided samples are subsequently transferred to the N2 glove box chamber to be placed in the XPS holder equipped with indium foil. The BE and intensities for chemical quantification are determined after subtraction of a Shirley-type background from the photoemission spectra via Casa XPS software. Bulk density was measured using a 10 mL graduated cylinder, where 1.0 g of catalyst was placed. This material was previously sieved with a 125–180 μm particle size. The cylinder was gently tapped, and the occupied volume was recorded. 2.4 Sample activation The NiW/AlY-x materials were activated by in situ sulfidation in a homemade stainless steel continuous flow reactor (di=0.8 cm) filled with approximately 40 mg of each catalyst sieved with a particle size between 125–180 μm. The samples were dried with N2 flow at 120 °C (heating rate of 5 °C·min−1) for 0.5 h. Then, the temperature was increased to 400 °C (5 °C·min−1), and the stream was switched to a mixed flow of H2/H2S (15 % v/v H2S; hydrogen balance), maintaining these conditions for 4 h. The samples for XPS analysis were kept in an inert atmosphere chamber filled with N2, maintaining positive pressure. The sulfided samples for HRTEM analysis were suspended in ethanol and kept in the glove box chamber. 2.5 Catalytic evaluation 2.5.1 Continuous flow reaction test The hydrodesulfurization reaction was conducted in the same packed-bed tubular reactor as that mentioned in the previous section, operating under atmospheric pressure. 3-methyl-thiophene was used as a model molecule. The catalyst activation was carried out using 40 cm³ ·min−1 H₂S flux at 400 °C with a heating ramp of 5 °C·min−1 for 2 h. A reaction flux of 40 cm³ ·min−1 of H₂ was sent to the saturator, where liquid 3-methyl-thiophene was maintained at 20 °C, and the saturated gas flux resulting in a 3MT molar flow equal to F3MT = 6.7 × 10 −7 mol·s−1 was directed to the tubular reactor and finally to an online chromatograph to quantify the reactant and products. The catalytic reaction was tested in a temperature range of 200 °C to 320 °C using approximately 50–100 mg of the preactivated catalyst sieved between 80 mesh (180 μm) and 120 mesh (125 μm). The average conversion values were obtained from five samples taken at each temperature stage to ensure steady-state conditions. The steady-state reaction rate was calculated via Eq. (1). (1) r = ( F 3 MT * x 3 MT ̅ ) m cat where F3MT is the 3MT molar flow, x 3 MT ̅ is the average conversion and mcat is the mass of the catalyst used in each experiment. 2.5.2 Batch reactor catalytic test The HDS of dibenzothiophene (DBT) (Aldrich Chemical, 98 %) was performed in a 500 mL batch Parr reactor, which was magnetically stirred (700 rpm). The conditions of the tests were as follows: temperature of 320 °C under a hydrogen atmosphere of 5.516 MPa, 200 mg of sulfided catalyst and 500 ppm of sulfur from DBT (1.22 ×10−3 mol) dissolved in 100 mL of hexadecane (Aldrich Chemical, 99 %). The reactor was flushed with nitrogen and heated under stirring until the reaction temperature was reached. The nitrogen was then removed, and hydrogen was introduced (Ptot = 5.516 MPa). The reaction time was subsequently determined. The total pressure was maintained at a constant level throughout the reaction by adding hydrogen, only as needed, to compensate for its consumption. The samples were periodically collected and analyzed quantitatively via gas chromatography for five hours. The catalytic activity was expressed as the initial reaction rate (mol DBT transformed per second and per gram of catalyst). The initial reaction rate was determined from the linear portion of the concentrationtime plot. For the HDS of DBT, the obtained products were biphenyl followed by cyclohexylbenzene and negligible traces of dicyclohexyl. No evidence of cracking products that could be volatile under sampling conditions, such as benzene or cyclohexane, were observed. 3 Results In this section, we summarize all the results obtained from the different techniques for the AlY-x supports, oxide state and sulfide state NiW/AlY-x catalysts and then the catalytic activity test in two model molecules of gasoline and diesel cuts. With all the evidence obtained, we present an integral discussion and propose some trends and activitystructure correlations. 3.1 Support characterization 3.1.1 Thermogravimetric analysis of noncalcined AlY-x supports Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to evaluate the decomposition profile and thermal stability of the AlY-x sample as a function of the yttrium oxide content. The TGA curves of the AlY-x samples are shown in Fig. 1. We obtained a weight loss of approximately 79.5 % for AlY-0, whereas AlY-0.5, AlY-1.0, and AlY-1.5 presented weight loss percentages of 82.4, 80.2, and 82.7, respectively. The decomposition profile clearly changed with the addition of yttrium. The yttrium-containing samples reached a plateau at approximately 550 °C, in contrast to AlY-0, which stabilized until 650 °C. The DTGA curves presented in the supplementary information as Figure S1 show visible similarities for the yttrium samples, which present three main weight losses at approximately 135 °C, 260 °C, and 380 °C; on the other hand, the AlY-0 peaks are at approximately 135 °C, and the broad peak is centered at 305 °C. Additionally, AlY-0 has two distinguishable shoulders at 180 °C and 230 °C. The peak centered at 135 °C is attributed to the dehydration of adsorbed water and the evaporation of the excess structure, directing agent P123, which occurs at 150 °C [39]. The second peak is related to nitrate decomposition, and the final peak is attributed to the complete oxidation of the carbon material from citrate and the surfactant precursor [40–42]. The peaks at 180 °C and 230 °C could be attributed to dehydration and oxidation of citric acid. The primary difference between the AlY-0 and the yttrium samples lies in the delayed nitrate or carbon species decomposition. In the yttrium samples, the assigned peak is centered near 265 °C, whereas AlY-0 displayed this weight loss centered at 307 °C. This could be attributed to the decomposition of the remaining free citric acid [43]. Among the yttrium samples, AlY-1.5 presented a steeper weight loss in the first stage, which could be related to dehydration and evaporation of P123. An interesting characteristic of AlY-1.5 is the weight gain displayed between 570 °C and 800 °C, which is probably due to oxygen uptake, in contrast to all the other samples, which show a constant weight decrease (Figure S2). 3.1.2 Textural properties Fig. 2A shows the obtained nitrogen physisorption isotherms and the pore size distributions of the AlY-x materials. In general, the samples exhibited type IV isotherms, indicating their mesoporous nature, as evidenced by the distinct hysteresis loop and adsorbed volume. Like the H5 hysteresis loop type, AlY-0 features low nitrogen adsorption and a distinctive steep step down due to cavitation, indicating open and partially blocked mesopores with a wide size distribution [44]. On the other hand, AlY-0.5 and AlY-1.0 substantially increased the absorbed volume and H2 hysteresis type, with the main difference being the presence of a step down in the desorption tail near the capillary point in AlY-0.5. Finally, AlY-1.5 presents an H2 hysteresis type with a lower adsorbed volume. Table 1 presents the results for the specific surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter. The SBET for the yttrium-free sample (AlY-0) was 55 m2·g−1. The inclusion of yttrium drastically increased the SBET for the AlY-0.5 sample, with an almost 2.15 times greater surface area. Furthermore, the increase in yield of the AlY-1.0 sample resulted in another increase of approximately 27 % compared with that of the AlY-0.5 sample. However, the AlY-1.5 sample presented a decrease to 100 m2·g−1, forming a volcano curve as a function of the yttrium content. In terms of the pore size distribution ( Fig. 2B), AlY-0 has a wider pore size distribution than the other materials do, with a pore size distribution centered between 4–5 nm. In contrast, AlY-0.5 and AlY-1.0 display unimodal pore distributions centered at 8.7 nm and 6.6 nm, respectively. The AlY-1.5 material presented a unimodal distribution but a lower value, centered at 4.6 nm. In general, the incorporation of yttrium leads to a narrower pore size distribution, whereas the continuous increase in the yttrium content diminishes the pore size. 3.1.3 Temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 A CO2-TPD study was conducted to quantify the basic sites of support. Previous studies have suggested that the presence of yttrium in a mixed oxide material could provide basic sites [35]. The values obtained for the total number of basic sites for the different supports are also displayed in Table 1. The quantity of CO2 adsorbed by the AlY-0 sample was 9.0 μmol·g−1, whereas that of the AlY-0.5 sample was approximately 4.5 times greater than that of the yttrium-free sample (AlY-0), confirming the clear increase in the surface CO2 adsorption capacity when yttrium was incorporated as a mixed oxide. Nevertheless, further increases in the yttrium content appear to decrease CO2 adsorption, indicating that the optimal content could be rather low. Another effect that could decrease CO2 adsorption is the modification of the electrostatic properties of materials, which depend on the mixed oxide species formed at the surface. 3.1.4 Zeta potential Zeta potential measurements were conducted to obtain the isoelectric points (IEPs) of the materials as a function of pH for the AlY-x samples (Table 1). Fig. 3 displays the obtained zeta potential vs pH curves for IEP estimation at the point at which the curves intersect with the pH axis. Compared with the yttrium-free sample, the AlY-0.5 sample clearly presented an acid shift with an IEP at a pH of 9.3. However, as in the previous section, a further increase in the yttrium content returns the IEP to higher values. The trend in the pH at which the IEP was obtained was as follows: AlY-1.5 > AlY-0 >AlY-1.0 >AlY-0.5. Notably, the IEP of these AlY-x materials is close to the values reported for γ-alumina (pH ∼ 8.5–9.5) [45,46] and for yttria (pH ∼ 7.5–8.5) [47]. 3.1.5 Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy analysis Fig. 3B displays the UVVis spectra of the AlY-x materials. First, the spectrum of the AlY-0 sample clearly differed from that of the yttrium-containing samples. Notably, alumina typically presents only a low-intensity shoulder, most likely related to the interband transitions rather than to ligandmetal charge transfer transitions related to O2- to Al3+, as reported previously [35]. However, in this AlY-0 sample, it appears that the alumina prepared via this method presents large quantities of tetrahedral (280 nm) and octahedral (320 nm) species. In fact, both species appear to have approximately the same F(R) intensity. In this spectrum, another shoulder was observed at approximately 450 nm, which was probably related to segregated large octahedral species. An analysis of the spectra of the yttrium-containing materials revealed that this shoulder shifted to 350 nm. This absorption could be attributed to defects in the support matrix. The optical band gaps for the samples were calculated via a corrected Tauc method [48]. Tauc plots are provided in the supplementary information (Fig. S3), and the obtained values are displayed in Table 1. The average optical band gap was close to 6 eV, with the highest value of 6.1 eV for the AlY-0 material, whereas for the yttrium materials, the lowest value of 5.4 eV was obtained for the AlY-1.5 sample. 3.1.6 X-ray diffraction analysis Fig. 4 displays the wide-angle diffractograms of the AlY-x materials. Only the AlY-0 sample presented crystallographic reflections related to the γ-alumina phase, with no peaks associated with other alumina phases, such as corundum. The AlY-0.5, AlY-1.0 and AlY-1.5 samples only display an amorphous phase, with a broad signal between the 16° and 38° 2θ positions, indicating a possible solid solution. For sample AlY-0, two peaks are visible at 2θ values of 66.6° and 46.1°, which can be indexed to the (400) and (440) planes according to the 01–011–0403 card. Notably, there is a broad reflection between the 55° and 64° 2θ positions that can also be indexed as the reflection of (333), which is present in the structure of γ-alumina. The corresponding reflections of the other families of planes, such as (200), (311) and (222), that are present at 2θ angles of approximately 25–40° were not visible, although a broad peak was present around this region, indicating the possible formation of low short crystallinity. 3.1.7 Supports HRTEM analysis The TEM micrographs are shown in Fig. 5 and confirmed that the AlY-x materials exhibited pseudo-ordered porosity. For each sample, pore size measurements were collected to obtain the average pore size, and histograms of the pore size length are provided in the Supplementary Information. The micrograph provided in Fig. 5A was obtained from the AlY-0 sample and shows parallel lateral channels approximately 200 nm in length. The average pore diameter was 8.9 ± 4.4 nm; for this sample, the pore diameter was approximately 13 nm, whereas the pore size around the channel varied from approximately 4 to 5 nm; the histogram is presented in the SI (Fig. S4). The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern indicated the presence of the (400) and 440) planes, which confirmed the presence of short crystalline γ-alumina in the AlY-0.0 sample (inset in Fig. 5A). If we suppose that the pore walls are formed by the γ-alumina phase doped with yttrium, it must contain the main plane (4 4 0); therefore, the pores will be located at this plane, whereas the observed channels (lateral view) must be located in the normal plane (1−1 0). Fig. 5B shows that the AlY-0.5 system has a more organized and homogeneous pore structure than does the AlY-0.0 sample. In this case, the average pore size was 7.8 ± 2.5 nm. For sample AlY-1.0, the pores are viewed from the [110] orientation (Fig. 5C). The calculated average diameter remains similar with respect to that of AlY-0.5, with a value of 7.7 ± 1.5 nm. In both cases, for AlY-0.5 and AlY-1.0, the size distributions are unimodal, as shown in Fig. S4. Finally, the micrograph from the AlY-1.5 sample (Fig. 5D) exhibited domains of ordered porosity and amorphous zones. The pore size decreased compared with that of the previous samples, with an average value of 5.1 ± 1.0 nm. Although all the materials present pseudo-order characteristics, yttrium incorporation leads to a narrower pore size distribution than the broader distribution obtained for the AlY-0. 3.1.8 XPS analysis of the AlY-x samples The survey spectra of the AlY-x samples revealed photopeaks related to yttrium, aluminum, oxygen, and carbon atoms (not shown here). Therefore, high-resolution spectra for the Y 3d, Al 2p, O 1 s and C 1 s orbitals were acquired and are shown in Fig. 6. All the spectra were first calibrated using the C 1 s peak of adventitious carbon (284.8 eV) as a reference (see Fig. S5). In Fig. 6A, the electrons arising from the Al 2p orbital were observed to be centered at 74.8 eV, with a slight shift toward a lower binding energy depending on the yttrium content. In Fig. 6B, the emission line region presents one high-intensity peak with two shoulders related to the spinorbit splitting of Y 3d5/2 and Y 3d3/2; in this case, the binding energy for Y 3d5/2 was 158.2 eV, with an energy shift (Δ) for Y 3d3/2 of 2.05 eV in all the yttrium-containing samples. In this case, there was no observable shift in the BE. In contrast, for the O 1 s region in the AlY-x samples (Fig. 6C), a similar trend was observed as that in the Al 2p region, in which the BE position changed with respect to the Y content [49]. The XPS surface chemical composition is provided in Table 2. As seen, the %at. The composition of AlY-0 coincides with the formula for alumina. The samples with yttrium presented slightly higher at% values for oxygen than did the samples with Al at% content. As expected, the Y at% content increased as the Y/Al ratio increased, reaching a maximum of 2.2 at% in the AlY-1.5. The at% values of O and C remained almost constant, with average values of 55.1 at% and 9.0 at%, respectively. The metal composition was also determined through TEMEDS and ICPOES characterization techniques (the values are included in Table 2). The Y/Al ratios obtained via both bulk techniques were similar to those obtained via the XPS results for the surface. Notably, TEMEDS showed a slight deviation only in the value for the AlY-1.0 sample, whereas ICPOES varied in the value obtained for the AlY-1.5 sample. The aluminum and yttrium core emission line regions are straightforward to fit since only one species for each metal could be present at the surface related to alumina and yttria. However, the O 1 s high-resolution spectra present a widening that is possibly associated with the presence of multiple species, i.e., oxygen atoms in the lattice (Olat), defects (Odef) and OH groups (OOH) [50,51]. Therefore, we present the fit in the O 1 s region considering those three species, as shown in Fig. 6D, and the % species data are presented in Table 3. In this case, the Olat species increase almost linearly as the yttrium content increases, reaching approximately 55 % greater than that in the yttrium-free sample. Odef does not present observable changes, remaining almost constant at an average value of 49.9 %. Compared with those of the Olat species, the values of the OOH species decrease almost inversely, decreasing by almost 60 %. 3.2 Catalyst characterization The characterization of the catalyst series was conducted via the same techniques, and therefore, some of them were very similar. In those cases, the plots are presented in the supplementary information to avoid unnecessary extension of the manuscript. 3.2.1 N2 physisorption and composition bulk analysis The nitrogen adsorptiondesorption isotherms and BJH pore size distributions are provided in the Supplementary Information as Fig. S6. Compared with those of the supports, the adsorption and desorption isotherms and the hysteresis loop do not change. With respect to the textural properties ( Table 4), the obtained values for the surface area and pore volume are slightly lower than those of the support, and the values decrease by approximately 14–21 %. The pore size distribution is presented in Fig. S6B, and the statistical plot indicates that the pore size did not change in general terms. These results suggest that the pores were not filled or blocked by the active metals. The isotherms of the samples in the sulfided state are presented in Fig. S6C. The values of textural properties (see Table 4) remain almost equal within the uncertainty associated with the measuring instrument. A more notable change was observed for NiW/AlY-1.0, which passed from 131 to 117 m²·g−1 after being sulfided. The ICPOES chemical analysis results confirmed that the desired ratio of Ni to W was achieved for the materials. The %wt contents of Ni and W were similar to those reported for similar materials and lower than those reported for commercial catalysts. The results show that the atomic ratio is close to the nominal value (Table 4). 3.2.2 XRD XRD diffractograms were obtained for the NiW/AlY-x series in the oxide state. The diffractograms are presented in Fig. S7, and the patterns did not show any evidence of diffraction peaks related to nickel or tungsten oxide phase formation to the limit of detection of this technique. 3.2.3 DRS UVVis UVVis spectra are provided in the supplementary information as Fig. S8. Intense bands were observed at 250 nm and 437 nm. These absorption bands are assigned to the charge transfer transition of O2- to W+6, which exhibited an intense absorption band at approximately 200 nm to 350 nm. These bands could be related to the presence of tetrahedral (200–280 nm) and octahedral (280–350 nm) coordinated polymeric species depending on W atom aggregation. The second band centered at 430 nm is attributed to the presence of nickel octahedral species (Nioct 2+). In simple view, the spectra appear to be approximately the same for all the NiW/AlY-x samples, although zooming in on each region allowed us to observe small differences (see Figure S8B and S8C). For example, the NiW/AlY-1.0 (c) material presented a slightly broader band than the other supported materials did, as shown in Figure S8B. On the other hand, the highest yttrium content sample (NiW/AlY-1.5) presented a more intense band for Nioct 2+, as shown in Figure S8C. 3.2.4 XPS of sulfide state samples The results of semiquantitative chemical analysis obtained from the XPS spectra along with the Ni/(Ni+W) and Y/Al ratios are shown in Table 5. The XPS high resolution windows for C 1 s, O 1 s, and Al 2p are provided in supplementary information as Figure S9. The values for the C and O atoms were nearly constant. The yttrium atomic content increased as the nominal content increased from 1.5 at% in the NiW/AlY-0.5 sample to 3.1 in the highest content sample, i.e., NiW/AlY-1.5. As expected, the W and Ni contents at% vary with the Y nominal ratio, although the W content appears to be equal in the AlY-1.0 and AlY-1.5 samples with a W content of 1.2 at%. Similar observations could be made with Y and S at%, since both increase almost linearly with the nominal yttrium content. The only metal that presented the inverse behavior was aluminum since the content increased from 40.0 at% in the sample without yttrium to 34.0 in the NiW/AlY-1.5 catalysts. However, the content values are closely related to the surface areas since we impregnated with 2.8 Watoms·nm−2. Therefore, it seems more appropriate to compare the Y/Al and Ni/(Ni+W) atomic ratios. For the yttrium-doped materials, the Y/Al ratio differed from the nominal ratios presented in Table 2 and discussed in Section 3.1.8. In this case, the variation in the at% for yttrium atoms was 67 %, 44 % and 41 % compared with the values initially observed at the surface for the NiW/AlY-0.5, NiW/AlY-1.0 and NiW/AlY-1.5 samples, respectively. Notably, the Y/Al ratio increased to approximately 0.04, 0.06 and 0.09 for the NiW/AlY-0.5, NiW/AlY-1.0 and NiW/AlY-1.5 samples, respectively. This confirmed the enrichment of the surface with yttrium atoms. On the other hand, for the Ni/(Ni+W) ratio, the intended value was 0.31; however, the obtained values generally decreased to different degrees, i.e., for AlY-0.5 and AlY1.5, the value obtained for the Ni/(Ni+W) ratio was 0.26 in both cases. Moreover, for NiW/AlY-1.0, the value obtained was 0.24, which was the lowest value among the series. Furthermore, it is very important when analyzing sulfided samples to verify that after sulfidation, the samples do not have contact with atmospheric air prior to analysis. The presence of sulfate species at 168 eV could reveal whether the procedure was successful in preventing air contact. Indeed, as shown in Fig. 7A, the presence of one peak at 168 eV was not detected in any of the NiW/AlY-x sulfided samples. Fig. 7A also presents the fit performed in the S 2p core emission region, in which the contribution of the Y 3d orbital was also included. The electrons arising from the S 2p orbital present a doublet related to the spin-orbit splitting of S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2 at 161.7 eV, with a Δ shift of 1.18 eV. The main photopeak of Y 3d appeared at 157.9 eV and, in this case, also presented a spin orbit with a Δ shift of 2.05 eV. Fig. 7B presents the fit performed in the W 4 f core emission region for all the NiW/AlY-x-sulfided samples. In this case, the literature reports the possible presence of three tungsten species, namely, W+6, W+5 and W+4, at 35.9 eV, 33.1 eV and 32.1 eV, with a Δ shift of 2.18 eV for the spin-orbit species (W 4f7/2 and W 4f5/2), respectively [33,52–54]. These oxidation states are linked to the formation of WO3, WOxSy and WS2 to different degrees in the NiW/AlY-x-sulfided samples, depending on the yttrium content. Finally, the same phenomenon was observed in the Ni 2p3/2 core emission line region, in which three analogous species were considered after the sulfidation process (see Fig. 7C). The electron signal related to the NiS species appeared at 852.7 eV, whereas for NiO, the electron signal was set at 855.4 eV. The third species is typically related to the nonstoichiometric promotion of the WS2 active phase called the NiWS species and is set normally at 854.0 eV [32]. In this case, one satellite was also considered for each Ni species detected (a detailed description of the fit process is provided in the supplementary information as Annex 1). The semiquantitative analysis results derived from the fit are presented in Table 6. The WO3 species resulted in the maximum value in the NiW/AlY-1.0-sulfided sample, with 28.1 % for the WOxS species, and its maximum value was reported in the NiW/AlY-1.5-sulfided sample. The maximum WS2 content of 54.4 % was observed in the NiW/AlY-0.5-sulfided sample. In the case of Ni atoms, the NiS species presented its maximum contribution in the NiW/AlY-1.0-sulfided sample at 20.8 %, whereas for NiO, its maximum contribution was observed in the yttrium-free sulfided sample (NiW/AlY-0). In this case, the NiWS phase seems to increase with the presence of yttrium in the samples, reaching its maximum % in the NiW/AlY-1.5-sulfided sample. 3.3 HRTEM analysis of the NiW/AlY-x samples TEM micrographs of the NiW/AlY-x sulfided catalysts are displayed in Fig. 8. Overall, the presence of pseudo-ordered porosity in all the materials is similar to the observations previously acquired for the AlY-x supports presented in Section 3.1.7. This result confirms that the ordered pores are preserved after the thermal processes of impregnation-calcination and sulfidation. The visible pores appear along the [001] and [110] directions, as shown in Fig. 8A, B and C, for the NiW/AlY-0, NiW/AlY-0.5 and NiW/AlY-1.0 sulfided samples. In the case of NiW/AlY-1.5, the ordered porosity was no longer detected (Fig. 8D). At higher magnification, typical black lines related to the WS2 slabs were detected all over the surface of all the NiW/AlY-x sulfided catalysts. In principle, tungsten oxide species transform into WS2 nanoparticles, and their formation occurs inside the porous channels, forming active species at the surface and in the interior of the materials, as shown in Fig. 9. Additionally, WS2 slabs ranging in size from approximately 1 to 6 nm appear to take the rounded form of pores, presenting some curvature effects, as observed in Fig. 9B and C. In the case of sample NiW/AlY-0.5, it was possible to observe the formation of slabs across both the [001] and [110] pore directions (Fig. 9B). For NiW/AlY-1.5, the detected WS2 slabs were homogeneously distributed over the surface with apparently fewer stacking numbers. Histograms of the slab length and stacking degree for each sample are presented in Figure S10 and S11, respectively, and the statistical data are provided in Table 7. The average slab lengths were as follows: NiW/AlY-0 = 3.1 nm, NiW/AlY-0.5 = 2.6 nm, NiW/AlY-1.0 = 2.2 nm and NiW/AlY-1.5 = 2.6 nm. Following the method of Vrinat et al. [55], we calculated the ratio of W located at the edges (We) relative to the total W content (WTotal) in the slab, and these values are presented in Table 7. Briefly, the Vrinat method can quantify the atoms involved in a WS2 slab by using the average slab length and a geometric model where L= 2 n × dW-W (dW-W=0.316 Å) with n equal to the number of WW atoms. From there, it is possible to obtain the total W atoms forming the slab (WTotal=3 n2+3n+1) and those located at the edge (We=6 n). Thus, these values indicate that many atoms are located at the border for sample NiW/AlY-1.0 compared with sample AlY-0.0, which has a lower WEdge/WTotal ratio (0.33). 3.4 HDS reaction of 3-methylthiophene (3MT) The hydrodesulfurization reaction of 3MT was evaluated to verify the direct effect of yttrium as a dopant in the alumina matrix on the catalytic properties of the sulfided NiW/AlY-x series. Calculations to verify the absence of mass transfer limitations were performed, and the methods and data obtained are presented in the supplementary information as Annex 2. The Mears and Weiz-Prater criteria indicate that our measurements were free of axial, external, and internal mass transfer limitations [56,57]. The average conversion at steady-state conditions as a function of the reaction temperature is presented in Fig. 10A and ranges from 200 °C to 320 °C. As expected, the curves presented constant increases in the conversion as a function of the reaction temperature in all the cases. In the case of NiW/AlY-0, the conversion at 200 °C was below unity. Notably, the flow conditions were optimized to work under differential conditions; therefore, the conversion in most cases was less than 20 % at all temperatures except for NiW/AlY-1.0, which appeared to be the most active catalyst among the series. Considering the differential conditions, the steady reaction rates were calculated via mass balance for the continuous flow reactor, and the obtained values are presented in Fig. 10B. The maximum conversion was achieved at higher temperatures for the NiW/AlY-1.0 material, and a consistent trend in conversion was observed across all the studied temperatures: NiW/AlY-1.0 > NiW/AlY-0.5 > NiW/AlY-1.5 > NiW/AlY-0. Working under differential conditions also allowed us to obtain the activation energy and fairly compare the selectivity [58]. However, the 3MT model molecule is typically desulfurized via two pathways. The first, called hydrogenation (HYD), leads to 3-methyl tetrahydrothiophene (3MTHT), whereas the second is called direct desulfurization (DDS) since it forms isoprene. The hydrogenation route could be continued to obtain 3-methyl-1-butane thiol (3M1BT). This 3M1BT, in principle and under reaction conditions, could undergo the formation of 3-methyl-1-butene (3M1B), although literature mentions that this reaction is rather rare [59,60]. Similarly, isoprene can be partially saturated to 2-methyl-2-butene (2M2B), 2-methyl-1-butene (2M1B), or 3M1B. These butenes, also known as isoolefins (iC4), can be completely saturated to form 2-methylbutane (2MB) paraffin. Our experimental results revealed only the presence of 3MTHT, 2M1B, 2M2B, and 2MB, as summarized in Fig. 10C. The chromatographic peaks related to 3MB1T and 3M1B were not detectable, suggesting that the formation of iC4 could arise also from desulfurization of 3MTHT. The activation energies and selectivity obtained at 280 °C are provided in Table 8, while the conversion and product yields over time are presented in Figure S12. The 3MT selectivity values are discussed in Section 4.1 (vide infra). 3.5 HDS of dibenzothiophene (DBT) Fig. 11A displays the initial reaction rates obtained for all the NiW/AlY-x sulfided catalysts in the DBT hydrodesulfurization reaction using a batch Parr reactor. The influence of the support modified by the presence of yttrium was directly reflected in the catalytic activity of the NiW/AlY-x sulfided samples. NiW/AlY-0 presented the lowest value among the series, with only 27 × 10-−8 molDBT·gcat −1·s−1 for the initial reaction rate. The inclusion of yttrium provided 2.6 times more activity to the NiW/AlY-0.5 catalyst than to the yttrium-free catalyst. In the case of the NiW/AlY-1.0 catalyst, the activity increased by approximately 90 % compared with that of the NiW/AlY-0.5 catalyst and was almost five times greater than the value observed for the yttrium-free catalyst. A further increase in the yttrium loading led to a drastic decrease in the catalytic activity, as observed for NiW/AlY-1.5. Like 3MT HDS, the DBT model molecule is typically desulfurized via two main pathways: hydrogenation (HYD) and direct desulfurization (DDS). As in the case of the 3MT reaction, the first hydrogenation step leads to the formation of tetra-hydro-DBT (THTDBT), whereas DDS leads to biphenyl (BP). After the hydrogenation of one aromatic ring, the molecule undergoes desulfurization and travels to cyclohexyl-benzene (CHB), and by means of further hydrogenation, it arrives at bicyclohexyl (BCH) (see the reaction scheme in Fig. 11B). Our present results indicate that only at high DBT conversions are the hydrogenation products (CHB and BCH) observed. These results imply that these products compete for active sites when the DBT concentration decreases. Therefore, we present the selectivity values in Table 9 at 20 % conversion to avoid misinterpretation of the selectivity values, but these values will be discussed in Section 4.1 (vide infra). Furthermore, the evolution of the conversion and product yield with time on stream is presented in Figure S13. 4 General discussion In general, the AlY-x mixed oxide materials presented suitable properties for the intended applications after calcination. In particular, the AlY-1.0 support presented the highest surface area among the materials, with a wide unimodal distribution centered at approximately 10 nm. The hysteresis loops in the yttrium-containing samples presented very different profiles than those observed for the AlY-0 sample. These findings indicate the beneficial effect of the presence of yttrium. In fact, the pore volume and average pore size increase almost twofold in the AlY-0.5 and AlY-1.0 samples, whereas the AlY-1.5 decreases again to near the alumina values (AlY-0). In addition, the statistical pore size distribution results presented in Fig. 1A indicate that the incorporation of yttrium in alumina enhances the symmetry of the pore size distribution. The gradual increase in yttrium content shift the pore size distribution to larger size values. The surface of the AlY-x samples was also characterized, revealing an apparent increase in the CO2 adsorption capacity with increasing yttrium content. Köck et al. reported CO2 absorption on pure yttria, revealing the formation of mono- and bidentate bonds with MeO- basic sites [61]. Therefore, we can assume that the number of basic sites increases with the presence of yttrium, as observed in Table 1. This was directly reflected in the values obtained for the pH needed to reach the isoelectric point, which decreased to 8.0 for the AlY-0.5. However, the behavior reverts to 9.0 and 9.4 in the AlY-1.0 and AlY-1.5 samples, potentially due to a decrease in the yttrium dispersion. However, the coordination observed by DRS analysis indicated that tetrahedral species increase with increasing yttrium content, suggesting that dispersion does not decrease. To gain insight into this matter, XPS analysis was performed. The O 1 s fit revealed that the yttrium content reduces the number of OH adsorbed species, suggesting that yttrium occupies those sites. This, in turn, must increase the O species in the lattice, an effect that was indeed observed, as shown in Table 3. In addition, the gradual increase in the yttrium content may reduce the quantity of defects and simultaneously increase the amount of surface oxygen. This effect was revealed by the zeta potential and TPD-CO2 measurements. Tables 2 and 6 also confirm that yttrium is preferentially located on the surface at low atomic contents. A higher yttrium content appears to promote the incorporation of oxygen into the surface and into the outer lattice. These observations are consistent with our previous theoretical studies, which indicated that yttrium atoms preferentially occupy sites in the first surface layer [36]. Therefore, Y atoms are expected to substitute for Al atoms, primarily in the outermost surface layer. With this in mind, we suggest that yttrium atoms close to the alumina outer surface induce a decrease in the OOH adsorbed and increase the O in the lattice, as shown in the oversimplified images (left and right) presented in Scheme 1. This effect also explains the increase observed in the tetrahedral species and the slight increase in the nominal Y/Al ratio obtained by XPS analysis with increasing yttrium content. Previous reports have shown that yttrium can improve the thermal stability of different structures [30,61,62]. In this direction, we observed that the XRD analysis of the AlY-x supports presented only a wide amorphous profile in all the samples. The evidence obtained from the TGA analysis indicated that the thermal stability is influenced by the yttrium content. Additionally, the DTGA analysis indicated small delays in the decomposition of nitrates and carbonaceous compounds as the yttrium content increased in the samples. Therefore, to elucidate the effects of yttrium on mixed oxide crystallinity and stability, the AlY-x materials previously calcined at 800 °C were subjected to another calcination procedure at 1000 °C, and the collected diffractograms are shown in Fig. 12. First, sharper peaks were obtained for the AlY-0 sample, indicating an increase in its short-range crystallinity. Notably, different reflections were obtained at this temperature for the AlY-0 sample than those presented in the XRD analysis (Fig. 4A). These new peaks appear to be related to the θ phase of alumina, as indicated by the JCPDS 00–011–0517 data sheet. Second, for the AlY-0.5 and AlY-1.0 yttrium-containing materials, reflections associated with γ-alumina (JCPDS 01–077–0403) were observed. Although AlY-1.5 presents γ-alumina diffractions, it also shows small peaks related to an aluminum yttrium oxide phase (Al5Y3O12).However, this phase was observed only for the material calcined at 1000 °C, and there is no evidence of its presence for the supports calcined at 800 °C. This evidence suggests that adding yttrium stabilizes the γ-alumina matrix, thereby hindering the formation of the monoclinic structure that typically occurs in its absence. HRTEM analysis revealed evidence of an ordered mesoporous structure in the AlY-x samples, as shown in Fig. 5. The porous channels confirmed the pore size distribution observed in the N2 physisorption analysis presented in Section 3.1.1. Early reports mentioned that other precursors, such as aluminum tri-tert-butoxide, perform similar syntheses, obtaining well-ordered mesoporous alumina [14]. However, in our procedure, the use of aluminum nitrate optimized the synthesis and reduced production costs. Furthermore, the preparation of the NiW catalysts using the AlY-x samples resulted in materials that preserved the ordered porosity. The evidence obtained from N2 physisorption of the oxide and sulfide state materials presented in Section 3.2.1 confirms that porosity remains present even after two sequential thermal treatments aimed at stabilizing and activating the catalysts. Additionally, the Ni and W active metals were well dispersed over the supports, as they did not block the pores, decreasing the pore volume or the surface area. Likewise, the catalyst samples appear to be adequate for the intended application, i.e., the reported hydrodynamic size of DBT, the largest model molecule or possible product used in this work, is approximately 0.45 nm [63]. This finding indicates that DBT, 3MT, and reaction products could easily diffuse into the pores of the catalytic samples; however, the calculation of effective diffusivity could help to obtain a measurable parameter to confirm this assumption. The effective diffusion coefficient (Deff) can be obtained via the reaction kinetics method and the effectiveness factor (h), as proposed by Wang et al. [64]. We consider that hydrodesulfurization reactions are irreversible, that hydrogen is the reactant in excess, and that the reaction can be evaluated under intrinsic conditions. Therefore, h=rapp/rint was taken as 1, as proven in [65]. Additionally, we assume that there was no deactivation during the catalyst evaluations. With these premises, we can move forward to calculate the Weisz modulus (ɸ), which can be calculated via Eq. (2): (2) ɸ = r s L c 2 D eff C s < 0.15 where rs is the initial specific reaction rate (kmolDBT m−3 s−1) for a batch reactor system related to each catalyst, Lc (m) is the characteristic dimension of the active layer, and it can be assumed that the active sites are homogeneously dispersed in the spherical particle; thus, L is equal to dp/6 (the average particle diameter (dp)) [66]. Cs is the reactant concentration at the external particle surface; however, in a perfectly mixed tank, the reactant concentration at the external particle surface Cs is equal to the reactant concentration in the bulk of the reaction solution CB (kmolDBT L−1). Dm is the diffusivity factor through the catalyst pores estimated via the Wilke–Chang correlation (Eq. 3) [67] (3) D m = 7.4 x 10 − 10 ( a M w ) 0.5 T μ V 0.6 where Dm is related to dibenzothiophene in hexadecane (m2 s−1), a is the association parameter (hexadecane=1), Mw is the solvent molecular weight (226.4 g mol−1), T is the absolute temperature (593 K), μ is the solvent solution viscosity (∼0.1998 centipoises) and V is the molar volume of solute at the normal boiling point (232.8 cm3·mol−1). Therefore, the value obtained for Dm was 1.26 × 10−6 m2·s−1. To include our catalyst properties in this calculation, we need the bulk density for each sample. The values obtained experimentally were as follows: 0.76, 0.71, 0.72 and 0.85 g·cm3 for NiW/AlY-0, NiW/AlY-0.5, NiW/AlY-1.0 and NiW/AlY-1.5, respectively. Now, we can take the bulk density to obtain the solid volume per gram, take the inverse of the bulk density and then sum this value to the pore volume (from Table 4) to obtain the total volume. If we divide the pore volume by the total volume, we obtain the void fraction (θ). The void fraction is used to obtain the effective diffusion coefficient Deff via Eq. (4). (4) D eff = D m θ 2 The calculated values are presented in Table 10. The values of Deff for the NiW/AlY-0.5 and NiW/AlY-1.0 samples indicate that DBT could diffuse almost three times faster than the NiW/AlY-0 and NiW/AlY-1.5 samples. However, the Weisz modulus was far below 0.15 in all the cases, indicating that the overall catalytic processes are free of internal diffusion limitations. 4.1 Structure–activity correlations A comparison of different molecules used in the hydrodesulfurization reactions tested in this work revealed that the overall performance trend was similar in both systems, as reported in other studies [32]. However, the reason for these findings is normally a compromise between several variables, such as the average stacking number, slab length, dispersion, and metal support interaction, which impact the degree of sulfidation, promotion or metal loading. For our samples, the tungsten loading density and Ni promotion ratio were set to fixed values, as indicated in Section 2. The ICP results of the oxide state catalysts, presented in Table 4, indicate that the Ni/(Ni+W) promotion ratio in the bulk was approximately the same for all the catalysts prepared and near the nominal value intended. On the other hand, the XPS results of the samples after the sulfidation process indicate that the Ni/(Ni+W) promotion ratio is lower at the surface, at approximately 0.26 on average. In this case, the dispersion of the active phases measured by TEM and their statistical analysis to obtain the stacking number and the slab length indicated that the amount of yttrium induced decreases in both parameters. A shorter average slab length indicates better dispersion, which in turn increases the number of slabs in the sample. Consequently, more active sites would be present, as these are located at the corners and borders of the promoted slabs. In this direction, the Ni participating in the nonstoichiometric NiWS phase is well recognized as a promoter species [68], but this phase is also related to the direct desulfurization pathway [32,33]. It is possible to relate the WEdge/WTotal ratio (Section 3.3) to the catalytic activity. By combining this information with the chemical composition data obtained from ICPOES and XPS semiquantitative analyses, we can estimate the total number of tungsten atoms forming the active phase and the total number of Ni atoms promoting WS2. These estimations serve to correlate the results of catalytic activity for both reactions, as shown in Fig. 13A. The activity evidence indicates that the quantity of Ni in the NiWS phase correlates well with the activity trend observed in both systems. The formation of a volcano curve as a function of the yttrium content confirmed that modifying alumina with this atom can enhance the catalytic performance. As a second point, we have the selectivity that, in the case of 3MT, direct desulfurization to iC4 is the most plausible step since the production of 2MB paraffin was very low in all cases and 3MTHT was barely detected. In the case of DBT selectivity, biphenyl was almost the only unique product observed. As mentioned before, once BP reaches sufficient concentration, this product competes against DBT for the active sites, and hydrogenation increases, as can be observed in the selectivity plots provided in the supplementary information (Figure S14). Nevertheless, under fair conditions (all at 20 % conversion), the comparison between samples indicates that the DDS pathway is where the enhancements were more important. As shown in Fig. 13B, the reaction rates of the DDS and HYD routes were separated to more effectively show the effect of yttrium on the activity through the DDS route. Notably, the stability and porosity of yttrium-containing materials also play a very important role in their activity. First, the textural properties were not significantly affected by the different thermal treatments after the initial synthesis, i.e., the impregnation procedure with a calcination step at 450 °C and the activation step at 400 °C. The evidence indicates that calcining the samples at 800 °C to stabilize the alumina-doped systems could improve and stabilize the metal support interaction. We label our materials as “pseudo-ordered” because low-angle XRD does not provide traditional evidence of the pore arrangement. However, this phenomenon was clearly observed by TEM even after the sulfidation process, as shown in Figs. 8 and 9. Moreover, when the effect of the textural properties was evaluated to obtain effective diffusivity, this parameter indicated that DBT could diffuse better (3 times) in the samples with this pseudo-ordered porosity. These NiW/AlY-x catalysts are highly active under two very different evaluation conditions. The evaluation of DBT (a diesel model molecule) in the liquid phase at high hydrogen pressures indicates that the nature of the catalysts is affected by the direct desulfurization route rather than by evaluation conditions. This fact could be highly convenient for heavy crude oil HDS units in refineries worldwide, as hydrogen consumption via this route is minimal. Consequently, the hydrogen ratio fed to the reactor may have decreased. Conversely, deep HDS of fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) naphtha requires catalysts with low hydrogenation properties. Indeed, the 3MT catalytic tests confirmed the low hydrogenation properties of our materials. Here, we observed that all the NiW/AlY-x catalysts maintained full olefin saturation below 15 %. Considering that FCC naphtha contains aromatics, olefins, and iso-olefins, which help achieve high octane number standards and that this stream contributes approximately 90 % of total sulfur compounds. 5 Conclusions In this work, we demonstrated that the incorporation of yttrium into the alumina matrix significantly improved the physicochemical properties and indirectly improved the performance of the NiW/AlY-x samples. In particular, the AlY-1.0 support had the highest surface area and pseudo-ordered porosity. The presence of yttrium influences the surface basicity, increases the CO₂ adsorption capacity, and modifies the distribution of oxygen species at the surface, as confirmed by zeta potential curves, UVVis DRS, and XPS techniques. Additionally, yttrium stabilizes the γ-alumina phase and delays thermal decomposition. Furthermore, HRTEM confirmed the presence of ordered mesoporosity even after multiple calcination steps. Notably, the NiW catalysts supported on the AlY-x materials maintained their porous structure with efficient mass transport and no diffusion limitations for the studied particle-size fraction. The results of the catalytic evaluations revealed a volcano curve correlation between the yttrium content and hydrodesulfurization activity, with the NiW/AlY-1.0-sulfided catalyst displaying greater performance among the series via the direct desulfurization route in both model molecules analyzed. This behavior is attributed to increased dispersion and promotion of active NiWS phases and enhanced metalsupport interactions. Therefore, the presence of yttrium impacts the metal support interaction, distribution, and dispersion of the active phases over the surface but does not directly affect the reaction mechanism. Overall, these findings confirm that yttrium doping is an effective strategy for tailoring the structure and function of alumina-based supports for advanced catalytic applications. coredata.dc:description: In recent years, publications on how to improve hydrodesulfurization catalysts have decreased considerably. However, the presence of sulfur compounds in oil cuts continues to increase and still represents a challenge to comply with environmental regulations. In this direction, improving hydrodesulfurization catalysts is of paramount importance. The present study focuses on combining two approaches to modify the alumina surface and bulk properties, namely, using an ordered porous structure and doping it with yttrium. We synthesized AlY-x (x as 0, 0.5, 1.0, and 1.5 yttrium substitutions in a alumina unit cell) materials via a one-pot solgel route assisted by citric acid and P-123. The samples were calcined at 800 °C and 1000 °C to determine their stability. The support samples were subsequently used to prepare NiW/AlY-x catalysts to be applied in hydrodesulfurization (HDS) reactions via 3-methyl-thiophene (3MT), dibenzothiophene (DBT), as naphtha and diesel sulfur model compounds. The results indicate that yttrium promotes stability, enhances textural properties, increases the CO2 adsorption capacity and changes the acidbase properties of the supports. In the case of the NiW/AlY-x catalyst, the presence of yttrium results in better dispersion, decreasing the WS2 slabs and improving the participation of Ni in the nonstoichiometric NiWS active phase . These improvements led to selectivity resulting almost exclusively from the direct desulfurization route. Among all the catalysts tested, NiW/AlY-1.0 resulted in approximately 4.6 times greater activity than the yttrium-free sample.

coredata.dc:title: Mesoporous pseudo-ordered alumina doped with yttrium as a support for NiW hydrodesulfurization catalysts
